THE KING'SSPEECH.(previous reference:Cabinet .25(29), Con-elusion 1.)i. The Cabinet had before them a second draft^f the King1 s Speech as agreed by the Cabinet attheir Meeting on June 26th, 1929 (Paper CP.-171(29)). (Appendix I.)The Cabinet approved the following altera-tions:-Third Paragraph, dealing with GermanReparations.. In the fourth line," for the words "the interestedPowers" put "representatives ofthe Governments concerned11.Ninth Paragraph: for the last word inthe paragraph, "settlement", put"migration".Tenth Paragraph, second line: Insertthe word "of" before the words"the ownership of the minerals".Thirteenth Paragraph,, dealing with housing and Slum Clearanceto be re-drafted to read asfollows:-"My Ministers propose to intro-duce legislation to promote an extensive policy of slum clearance and to make further provision for housing in urban and rural areas".GENERALELECTIONEXPERIENCES .(previous reference:Cabinet 24(29), Con-elusion 7 .)The following new Paragraph to beinserted immediately before the last paragraph:-"At the recent General Electionan extended franchise placed inthe hands of the whole of my people of adult years the graveresponsibility for guarding thewellbeing of this nation as a constitutional democracy and my government propose to have examined the experiences of theElection so that the working ofthe laws relating to Electionsmay be brought into conformitywith the new conditions".Subject to the above amendments theCabinet approved the King's Speech,a final draft of which is attached in Appendix II. SAFE GUARD IN of INDUSTRIES(previous reference:Oabinet 25(29), Con-elusion 3(c).)2. On the subject of Safeguarding ofIndustries the Cabinet agreed (a) To approve, as an addition to thedecisions taken at the previous meeting of the Cabinet referredto in the margin, the followingformula for the announcement inregard to the existing Safe-guarding Duties:-With regard to the existingSafeguarding Duties we have consistently opposed theirimposition and made itabundantly clear that weshould reserve the right toremove them when the practi-cable opportunity arose.Opposition to protective duties has just been over-whelrringly expressed by the electorate. It must there-fore be understood that weshould in no case renew these duties should they remain inoperation till the statutoryperiods expire and we reserve the right to repeal them atearlier dates if it appearspracticable and desirable todo so. We realise the incon-venience which changes of tariff policy inflict upon the trades concerned and in coming to conclusions on this matter wemust hav e regard to this con-sideration and also to therevenue aspects of the question.(b) That the Prime Minister should includethis statement in his speech on the address on the Opening of parliament and that the lord President of theCouncil should make a similar announce-ment in the House of Lords. EMPIRE TRADE. 3. Attention having been drawn to a telegram... . from the High Commissioner in Canada (No.152 of(Previous June 24th) on the subject of Empire Trade, fromReferenceCabinet 17 29) which it appeared that the Canadian Government hadConclusion 1.under consideration the possibility of summoningan interim Inter-Imperial Economic Conference ofthe Governments of the Empire in Canada, the cabinet invited the Secretary of State for Dominion affairs to circulate a Memorandum on the subject of empire trade covering not only the matters raised in theabove telegram but also the position in Australia,as emerging from recent telegrams, and in otherDominions.-3- GERMANY.4. The Cabinet had before them a MemorandumAssistance to by the Lord Privy Seal (Paper CP.-183 (29))public utility undertakings. covering a Report (Paper D.U. (29) 19) submittedto the Inter-Departmental Committee on Unemploy-(previous reference: ment by a Sub-Committee under the ChairmanshipCabinet 23(29), Con- 0f sir Warren Pisher. In this Report it waselusion 4.)suggested that, with a view to a progressiveUnemployment policy which should concentrateso far as possible upon measures which will and the economic development and equipment of thecountry and at the same time facilitate theTransfer and Training policy, the activitiesof the Unemployment Grants Committee in relationto revenue-producing schemes promoted by publicutility Companies should be merged in theGovernments wider plans for giving assistance tosuch schemes on a more extended basis includingrailways.In future these schemes should be dealt withby the Departments concerned, with the advice ofa small Expert Committee, the necessary financial provision being authorised by Parliament, forwhich purpose immediate legislation would benecessary to enable assistance to be given(by way of guarantee and/or grant) to ensure the putting in hand by railways and other publicutility undertakings of revenue-producing works.So far as guaranteed loans are concerned itwas proposed that in the first instance a limit should be set at 25,000,000, and that in additionany assistance by way of grant should be provided on the Departmental Votes. In his Memorandum the Lord Privy Seal askedfor the adoption of these j^proposals and that steps should be taken with a view to the preparation ofthe draft Bill in order that its provisions mightbe enacted before the August Recess .On the understanding that this measure wouldbe announced as part of the comprehensive policy for dealing with Unemployment now under considerationby the Lord Privy Seal, the Cabinet agreed To approve in principle the proposals in Paper C.P.-18S (29), subject tothe arrangement of details betweenthe Lord Privy Seal and theChancellor of the Exchequer.
